articles.author: jackrosa
articles.description: ~ in Vim toggles the case of the character under the cursor and then moves the cursor to the next character.
articles.title: Toggling Case with vim - #vim

articles.author: viniciusnegrisolo
articles.description:
dbg/2 macro. I was already using that nice macro to show the results on each step of a pipe execution on the logs, but I learned that if we use iex to start phoenix server then the dbg/2 calls will act like adding a breakpoints so we can pry on it. We need to start the server with:
iex -S mix phx.server
iex --dbg pry in order to swap the dbg implementation from the fancy IO output to the IEx.pry one.
articles.title: How to debug in Elixir - #elixir

articles.author: mattpolito
articles.description:
Ever do some sort of testing where you needed to block a specific request from completing in the browser? 

Me too... 

In chromium dev tools (Chrome, Brave, etc..) you can right-click a request in the network tab. You'll then be presented with an option to block the specific request or block the domain.

Next time that request is made, it will not complete. 

Easy-peasy
articles.title: Block network requests in browser dev tools - #testing

articles.author: tonyyunker
articles.description:
:Git to open vim-fugitive so I can easily navigate my modified and staged files. But that's 2 steps - 1 more than I want. 
nvim -c ":Git", where the -c is the command you want to execute on startup. For even fewer keystrokes you could create an alias!
articles.title: Execute (n)vim Commands on Startup - #vim

articles.author: marylee
articles.description:
slice_after (there's also slice_before, which behaves the same way).
array = [
  {activity: "traveling", ticket: "123"},
  {activity: "working", ticket: "123"},
  {activity: "awaiting_assignment", ticket: ""},
  {activity: "traveling", ticket: "234"},
  {activity: "refueling", ticket: "234"},
  {activity: "traveling", ticket: "234"},
  {activity: "working", ticket: "234"},
  {activity: "awaiting_assignment", ticket: ""}
]

array.slice_after { |i| i.activity == "awaiting_assignment" }
# Returns:
[
  [
    {activity: "traveling", ticket: "123"},
    {activity: "working", ticket: "123"},
    {activity: "awaiting_assignment", ticket: ""}
  ],
  [
    {activity: "traveling", ticket: "234"},
    {activity: "refueling", ticket: "234"},
    {activity: "traveling", ticket: "234"},
    {activity: "working", ticket: "234"},
    {activity: "awaiting_assignment", ticket: ""}
  ]
]
articles.title: Using slice_after to split arrays by a value  - #ruby

articles.author: jackrosa
articles.description:
https://realfavicongenerator.net/ can audit your website's favicon's to show which devices and browsers will display your favicon properly.   
 The site also helps with favicon generation and target resolutions.
articles.title: Check and generate your site's Favicons - #html-css

articles.author: gabrielreis
articles.description:
show timezone to see the current timezone on your postgres database:
my_db_test=# show timezone;
     TimeZone
------------------
 America/New_York
alter database my_db_test set timezone to 'utc';
psql session for the new timezone to apply.
articles.title: Updating Postgres Timezone - #sql

articles.author: jackrosa
articles.description: Cmd (⌘) + w in VS Code to close the currently open file.
articles.title: Close File Shortcut In VS Code - #workflow

articles.author: jackrosa
articles.description:
number < atom < reference < function < port < pid < tuple < map < list < bitstring
random_data = [["Hello World"], {:hello, :world}, 16, %{key: "value"}, :atom]
Enum.sort(random_data)
#=> [16, :atom, {:hello, :world}, %{key: "value"}, ["Hello World"]]
4 < :atom
#=> true
articles.title: Elixir Data Type Comparison - #elixir
